In a contrapositive argument, the truth of the conclusion is dependent on the truth of the premise. 

In this case, the premise is 'If Sue chose pizza, then Bob chose pasta', which can be written as 'Sue chose pizza → Bob chose pasta'. The conclusion is 'If Bob chose pasta, then Sue chose pizza', which can be written as 'Bob chose pasta → Sue chose pizza'. 

The contrapositive of the premise is 'If Bob did not choose pasta, then Sue did not choose pizza', which is logically equivalent to the conclusion. Since the conclusion is the contrapositive of the premise, the argument is logically valid.
